Application_Facts: Gonzalez fled Colombia due to threats from FARC and claimed refugee status in Canada, which was initially denied.
Procedural_Issue: Board did not adequately consider evidence on effectiveness of state protection
Evidence_Used: Credibility findings, evidence on Colombia's protection programs for targeted individuals
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to properly assess the ineffectiveness of state protection in Colombia
Credibility_Assessment: The Board found Gonzalez credible
Decision_Outcome: Initial denial of refugee claim by the Board
Outcome: Federal Court allowed judicial review, quashed the decision
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a protected person under refugee protection provisions
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of refugee claim by another member of the Board
Legal_Standard_Applied: Whether the applicant rebutted the presumption of state protection
Decision_Rationale: Board erred in concluding applicant failed to rebut presumption of state protection despite evidence showing Colombia's protection programs were ineffective for targeted individuals
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada

Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer erred in refusing the temporary resident visa application
Evidence_Assessment: The officer dismissed the application based on perceived weak family ties and insufficient financial resources, despite substantial evidence provided by the applicants
Decision_Outcome: Visa application denied
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate intent to leave Canada and meet admissibility requirements
Credibility_Factor: Applicants provided evidence of financial stability and familial ties
Legal_Rule: Under IRPA and its regulations, a visa can be issued if the officer is satisfied that the foreign national will leave Canada by the end of their authorized stay and meets other requirements
Grounds_for_Claim: Errors in decision-making process, including failure to consider relevant evidence
Outcome_on_Merits: The Federal Court found the decision unreasonable due to inadequate reasoning
Key_Evidence_Considered: Financial stability, familial ties in home country
Defendant_Response: Visa officer maintained refusal based on weak ties and finances
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of financial status and family connections
Outcome: Court allowed judicial review and remitted the matter for redetermination by a different visa officer

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: History of abuse, use of weapon (machete) in related incident
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk of harm upon return
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Consistent and coherent testimony
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 97(1)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to provide protection (non-criminal but relevant to immigration context)
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution due to family violence and lack of state protection
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Canadian refugee law, international protection obligations
Crimes.Protected_Group: Children at risk of domestic violence
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Police ineffectiveness, weak enforcement of protection orders
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Ongoing threat from private actor with no effective state intervention

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Use of deadly weapon, history of abuse, attack on minors
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Consistent accounts supported by documentation

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of RPD's decision on unfair prosecution
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: RPD failed to adequately assess detailed evidence, focusing on generalities
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On claimant to show well-founded fear of persecution
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Altun's status as Kurdish doctor and context of ethnic bias
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Prosecution can be persecutory if clearly unfair or politically motivated
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution due to unfair prosecution
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Personal circumstances, country conditions, judicial corruption in Turkey
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Not applicable – state actor (RPD) decision under review

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim based on ethnic persecution
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Well-founded fear of persecution due to Kurdish ethnicity
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Canadian refugee law, international protection principles
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: RPD decision set aside, remanded for new hearing
Crimes.Institutional_Action: RPD dismissed claim without proper analysis
Crimes.Targeted_Group: Ethnic Kurds perceived as supporting separatist movements
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Inadequate due to systemic bias and judicial corruption
Crimes.Credibility: Credible evidence of ethnic bias in prosecution
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Criminal prosecution used as tool of persecution

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Criminal conviction used as basis for refugee claim
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether forgery prosecution was pretext for persecution
Crimes.Governing_Law: Turkish criminal law, Canadian refugee law
Crimes.Outcome: RPD dismissal overturned, remanded for new hearing
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Altun's claim that conviction was politically motivated deemed plausible
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Country condition reports, personal testimony, legal documents
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 96 of IRPA, Turkish Penal Code
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Conviction was unjust and ethnically targeted
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Potential political motivation behind forgery charge
Crimes.Application_Error: RPD failed to consider evidence of judicial bias
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Detailed evidence on judicial corruption and ethnic discrimination in Turkey
Crimes.Application_Factor: Link between ethnicity and criminal prosecution
Crimes.Authority: Refugee Protection Division, Federal Court of Canada
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged forgery of documents in Turkey

Legal_Provision_Violated: subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee protection due to alleged persecution in Sri Lanka, specifically as an Eastern and Northern Tamil male facing significant persecution risks.
Procedural_Issue: Board dismissed the claim without adequately considering established country condition evidence regarding risk to Tamil males.
Evidence_Used: Evidence indicating persecution of Eastern and Northern Tamil males in Sri Lanka
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient consideration of objective country conditions and lack of emphasis on personal targeting despite group-based risk
Decision_Outcome: Board denied refugee status
Outcome: Federal Court allowed judicial review, found decision unreasonable
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of refugee claim
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness under subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Decision_Rationale: The Board unreasonably dismissed the claim by failing to recognize that members of the applicant's particular social group face significant risk of persecution in Sri Lanka.
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada

Legal_Issue: Whether the Board correctly applied the legal test for state protection
Governing_Law: Requirement of 'adequate protection' by the state, not merely 'serious efforts'
Evidence_Assessment: Assessment of safety in Walvis Bay and availability of internal flight alternative
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim initially rejected based on internal flight alternative
Burden_of_Proof: On claimant to demonstrate lack of adequate state protection
Legal_Rule: States must provide 'adequate protection' to citizens
Standard_of_Review: Correctness or reasonableness of legal test application
Grounds_for_Claim: Misapplication of legal test by focusing on 'serious efforts' instead of 'adequate protection'
Key_Evidence_Considered: Conditions in Walvis Bay, possibility of internal relocation
Legal_Framework: Refugee law, principles of state protection, domestic asylum procedures
Evidence_Type: Country condition evidence, legal argument on state protection standards
Outcome: Application for judicial review allowed; case remitted to differently constituted panel
Authority: Administrative tribunal (the Board), subject to judicial review by court

Application_Facts: Applicants fled Colombia after FARC demanded money, fearing for their lives.
Procedural_Issue: Board questioned credibility due to meeting FARC, not reporting threats, and quick departure.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board assumed adequate state protection without sufficient evidence analysis.
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility findings based on implausible actions without considering context.
Decision_Outcome: Board denied refugee status based on credibility and state protection issues.
Outcome: Judicial review granted; case remanded to a different Board member.
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of refugee claim.
Legal_Standard_Applied: Refugee claimants must overcome presumption of state protection unless clear evidence shows otherwise.
Decision_Rationale: Findings on credibility and state protection were unreasonable.

Criminality_Severity: High – credible fear of retaliation and death
Risk_Assessment: Significant risk due to targeted threats from FARC
Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on profession and perceived financial capacity
Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient contextual evidence of FARC threats
Evidence_Credibility: Applicants provided plausible explanations; Board failed to properly assess
Credibility_Assessment: Board unreasonably dismissed credibility despite coherent narrative

Sub_Crime_Type: Threat of kidnapping by armed group
Aggravating_Factors: History of FARC abductions for ransom or political leverage

Risk_Assessment: Elevated risk due to presence of FARC and lack of state control
Targeted_Victimization: Yes – professionals seen as financially viable targets
Evidence_Sufficiency: Contextual evidence supports risk; personal threats reported
Credibility_Assessment: Board’s skepticism not supported by contradictory evidence

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of credibility and state protection findings
Evidence_Assessment: Board failed to consider local context and specific risks
Decision_Outcome: Negative determination on credibility and state protection
Burden_of_Proof: On claimant to rebut presumption of state protection
Credibility_Factor: Implausibility of meeting FARC without detention questioned
Legal_Rule: Credibility findings require clear contradictions or implausibilities
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution by FARC due to extortion demands
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicants’ testimony, expert reports on Colombia
Legal_Framework: Refugee Convention, IRPA, jurisprudence on state protection
Defendant_Response: Board maintained denial based on credibility and protection assumptions

Criminality_Severity: High – part of systematic exploitation by insurgent group
Risk_Assessment: Serious and ongoing risk due to failure of state to protect
Risk_Nature: Forced financial contribution under threat of violence
Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on profession and perceived wealth
Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient evidence of extortion pattern and personal threat
Evidence_Credibility: Explanations consistent with known conditions in Colombia
Credibility_Assessment: Board unreasonably doubted applicants' account

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Roma family from Hungary claimed refugee status in Canada, citing persecution and lack of state protection; Board focused on applicants' interactions with police rather than operational adequacy of Hungary's protection measures
Procedural_Issue: Board failed to properly assess operational adequacy of state protection; focused on claimants' reporting behavior instead
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence showing inadequate protection for Roma in Hungary
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board ignored relevant documentary evidence on systemic persecution and state response
Decision_Outcome: Board’s decision found unreasonable
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division's decision
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of refugee claims by a different panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: State protection analysis under section 96
Decision_Rationale: Board erred by focusing on applicants' interactions with police rather than assessing the operational adequacy of Hungary's protection mechanisms for Roma

Nature_of_Acts: Threats from FARC due to a money laundering account dispute
Key_Evidence_Issue: Failure to prove inadequate state protection
Credibility_Assessment: Evidence accepted but insufficient to meet legal test
Standard_of_Proof: Claimants must prove inability or futility in seeking state protection
Legal_Provision_Cited: Section on state protection for refugee claims
Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim based on risk from non-state actors
Consequences_of_Action: Threats leading to flight from Colombia

Dispute_Type: Refugee claim involving threats due to corruption-related banking issue

Decision_Outcome: Denial of refugee claim
Burden_of_Proof: On claimants to show futility of seeking state protection
Credibility_Factor: Applicants did not seek police protection
Legal_Rule: State protection requires proof of inadequacy or futility
Standard_of_Review: Correctness for legal test, reasonableness for factual application
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution by FARC due to banking dispute

Sub_Crime_Type: Death threats by armed non-state actor
Aggravating_Factors: Specific targeting due to financial dispute
Prior_Criminality: FARC’s history of violence and extortion

Risk_Assessment: Serious personal risk upon return to Colombia

Credibility_Assessment: Consistent and truthful, but burden not met

Dispute_Type: Refugee claim arising from involvement in money laundering scheme
Legal_Issue: Availability of state protection for those threatened over financial crimes

Evidence_Assessment: Board relied on general security improvements
Decision_Outcome: Denial of refugee protection

Credibility_Factor: Relied on advice from army officer not to report
Legal_Rule: State protection must be assessed for specific individuals
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of FARC retaliation over money laundering account
Legal_Framework: Refugee determination process under Canadian law

Violation_Type: Decision unreasonableness due to evidentiary omissions
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section of IRPA relating to well-founded fear of persecution and state protection
Application_Facts: Applicants fled Venezuela alleging political persecution; incidents included vandalism and threats; claimed denial of refugee status was unjustified
Procedural_Issue: Failure to address key evidence; lack of transparency in decision-making
Evidence_Used: Incidents of vandalism, threats, DOS Report data
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Selective use of DOS Report; failure to consider evidence of political motive
Credibility_Assessment: Panel accepted incidents occurred but dismissed political motivation without adequate reasoning
Decision_Outcome: Refugee status denied by original panel
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision set aside
Remedy_Sought: Re-determination of refugee claim by a new panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution; availability of state protection
Decision_Rationale: Omission of key evidence and failure to properly assess political persecution rendered the decision unreasonable

Legal_Issue: Misapprehension of claim, confusion between state protection and Internal Flight Alternative (IFA)
Credibility_Assessment: Board accepted the applicant's story
Evidence_Type: Personal testimony, lack of evidence on state protection failure and IFA unreasonableness
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Existence of a viable Internal Flight Alternative (IFA) in Walvis Bay
Application_Error: Alleged misapprehension of facts by the Board
Legal_Standard: Burden of proof on applicant to show risk of persecution and rebut state protection presumption
Application_Factor: Failure to provide convincing evidence against state protection or IFA viability
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim dismissed; no refugee status granted

Application_Facts: Applicants' refugee claim denied based on presumed state protection without adequate analysis of personal risk evidence
Procedural_Issue: Board failed to address key evidence regarding Colombia’s inability to protect ELN-targeted individuals
No credibility findings made despite contradictory evidence
Evidence_Used: Expert evidence on country conditions in Colombia
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider personal risk in context of country conditions
Omission of critical evidence on state protection capacity
Credibility_Assessment: No credibility findings made by the Board despite conflicting evidence
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected based on presumed state protection
Remedy_Sought: Remand to a different decision-maker for reconsideration
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness of Board's decision
Requirement to assess personal risk and country conditions
Decision_Rationale: Board did not adequately justify conclusions on state protection or address personal risk evidence

Violation_Type: Failure to demonstrate lack of state protection
Application_Facts: Applicants faced threats from FARC but did not seek police help; claim of persecution due to political opinion or particular social group alleged
Procedural_Issue: Errors in credibility assessment
Judicial review on multiple grounds including nexus, credibility, state protection, and s. 97 analysis
Evidence_Used: Lack of engagement with state authorities
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of personal confrontation with perpetrators
Absence of documentary or corroborative evidence
Credibility_Assessment: Board found the applicants' story implausible due to lack of evidence and failure to seek police protection
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected by the Board
Relief_Sought: Overturning of Board's decision on refugee status
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's determination
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard applied to administrative decision
Decision_Rationale: State protection finding was reasonable despite credibility errors; applicants failed to prove lack of state protection and nexus to a Convention ground

Violation_Type: Failure to exhaust state protection avenues
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), section 96 or 97
Governing_Law: IRPA, Canadian jurisprudence on refugee claims and state protection
Application_Facts: Ms. Camacho fled spousal abuse in Venezuela and Trinidad without seeking police or state protection
Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant with domestic protection avenues in country of origin and transit
Procedural_Issue: Failure to demonstrate exceptional circumstances justifying non-exhaustion of state protections
Evidence_Used: Board's assessment of state resources in Venezuela and Trinidad, claimant's testimony
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of objective evidence supporting ineffectiveness of state protection
Credibility_Assessment: Claimant's doubts about state protection deemed objectively unreasonable
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of the Board's rejection of refugee claim
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard for availability and effectiveness of state protection
Decision_Rationale: In functioning democracies, claimants must exhaust state protection unless exceptional circumstances exist; none were proven here

Application_Facts: Applicant fled Mexico due to threats and assaults after reporting a drug transaction; reported incidents to authorities but received no protection
Procedural_Issue: Board Member incorrectly applied the legal standard by focusing on Mexico’s efforts rather than actual effectiveness of protection
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony, reports of threats and assaults, lack of response from Mexican authorities
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to assess effectiveness of state protection in Mexico
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected by Board Member
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision set aside
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a refugee in Canada
Remedy_Sought: Re-determination of refugee claim by a different Board Member
Legal_Standard_Applied: Balance of probabilities; adequacy and effectiveness of state protection
Decision_Rationale: Board failed to properly assess whether state protection was actually effective in Mexico; focus should be on effectiveness, not just existence of efforts
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Protection Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Aggravating_Factors: Fear of state authorities due to corruption
Risk_Assessment: Lower assessed risk by RPD based on protective resources
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence on state protection mechanisms
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicant's testimony credible but outweighed by state protection availability

No evidence of FARC activity in Bogota or threats against remaining family members

Crimes.Application_Facts: Ms. Dreta overstayed her visa, refugee claim was rejected, applied for H&C status based on family ties and best interests of the child
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant – remained in Canada after visa expiration
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: H&C application assessed internally without departure for permanent residence application
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of immigration officer to assess H&C claims within Canada despite requirement to apply from outside
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of exceptional hardship or compelling circumstances
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus on sufficiency of evidence

Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of immigration officer's decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably concluded that family support and financial stability mitigated hardship; no personal risk established in home country

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to apply for permanent residence from outside Canada as required by IRPA
Crimes.Application_Facts: Ms. Dreta sought exemption from requirement to apply for permanent residence from outside Canada via H&C application
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national with expired status, failed refugee claimant
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant – remained in Canada without authorization
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Attempt to obtain permanent residence without fulfilling procedural requirement to apply from outside Canada
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether officer had discretion to allow in-Canada H&C application despite statutory preference for out-of-country processing
Evidence_Used: Existence of family support in Canada
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of specific evidence demonstrating exceptional hardship or unique vulnerability
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No adverse finding; decision based on insufficient proof, not credibility
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Exemption from requirement to apply for permanent residence from outside Canada
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably exercised discretion, found no compelling reasons to justify exemption; family and financial supports present

Violation_Type: Failure to meet eligibility criteria for refugee status
Governing_Law: Administrative law principles on reasonableness and procedural fairness
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed religious persecution in Sudan
Female Applicant raised gender-related persecution claims
No durable solutions were demonstrated in Sudan
Country condition documentation not submitted by Applicants
Procedural_Issue: Adequacy of reasons provided by the Officer
Consideration of all relevant evidence
Procedural fairness in decision-making
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of sufficient evidence of persecution
Absence of country condition documentation
Unsubstantiated gender-related persecution claims
Credibility_Assessment: Gender-related persecution claims lacked narrative support
Religious persecution claims not compellingly demonstrated
Decision_Outcome: Immigration application denied
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of refusal decision
Granting of refugee status
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness
Procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: Officer provided adequate reasons
Decision based on facts and law
No duty to provide country condition reports absent sufficient applicant evidence
Claims not substantiated in narrative

Application_Facts: Respondent was absent for 630 days, falling short of the 1095-day physical presence requirement in the four years preceding the application
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship Judge's reasons were inadequate and failed to address key evidence gaps
Evidence_Used: Family presence in Canada, property ownership, community involvement
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of documentation on physical presence and financial ties to Canada
Decision_Outcome: Appeal allowed
Relief_Sought: Review of approval of citizenship application
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of the Citizenship Judge's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Pourghasemi, Koo, Papadogiorgakis residency tests
Decision_Rationale: Respondent did not meet the 1095-day physical presence requirement under any of the three legal tests; insufficient evidence and inadequate reasoning by the Citizenship Judge

Application_Facts: Applicant claims PRRA officer ignored relevant evidence about Sri Lanka's conditions; officer relied on general improvements in Sri Lanka’s conditions
Procedural_Issue: Selective use of country reports and omission of contrary evidence alleged
Evidence_Used: Country reports used selectively by PRRA officer
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Omission of evidence contrary to the officer's conclusions
Decision_Outcome: PRRA application denied
Relief_Sought: Successful PRRA application, reversal of removal risk assessment
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of PRRA decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Patent unreasonableness
Decision_Rationale: Officer's decision did not significantly misrepresent risk; cited evidence does not alter core claim of risk upon return

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 183 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Sodhi overstayed his visa, left Canada, and reapplied for a student visa; evidence showed attendance at Algonquin College after departure date.
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Not applicable – decision based on non-compliance, not false information
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged lack of procedural fairness in refusal
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No proof of studies in India during gap period
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer questioned credibility due to academic attendance in Canada post-departure
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Certification of general importance and quashing of refusal
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer’s decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably concluded re-entry without authorization based on applicant-provided evidence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Re-entering Canada without authorization under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Mr. Sodhi re-entered Canada illegally after deportation
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Transcripts and diploma indicated Canadian study post-2005 without valid status
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate lawful entry and compliance
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Lack of documentation supporting studies in India or lawful re-entry
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Applicants must prove they entered Canada legally and will comply with visa terms
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error in factual findings and procedural unfairness
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA sections related to admissibility and visa issuance
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Visa officer relied on applicant-submitted documents

Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Sodhi did not provide evidence of lawful status or explain presence in Canada after departure
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Deported individual reapplying for student visa
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: History of non-compliance with immigration status
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Implied omission of whereabouts and re-entry details
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Allegation that officer failed to give chance to respond to adverse inference
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Student transcripts, diploma, absence of Indian study records
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No documentation proving legal stay outside Canada or authorized re-entry
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer found applicant's explanation insufficient
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Visa refused due to credibility and compliance concerns
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: All evidence was provided by applicant; no procedural unfairness found

Violation_Type: Failure to provide justification and address contradictory evidence
Legal_Provision_Violated: Principles of administrative reasonableness, transparency, and intelligibility in decision-making
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), principles of administrative law
Application_Facts: Tibor and Rebeka Pinter's refugee claims involved allegations of persecution; similar facts were assessed differently by the Board and PRRA
Procedural_Issue: Board failed to address PRRA findings, inconsistent reasoning on persecution in education and employment
Evidence_Used: PRRA decision finding persecution, Board's own findings on state protection
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to reconcile or explain discrepancies with PRRA decision
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claims rejected by the Board
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's rejection of refugee claims
Remedy_Sought: Remittal of claims for reevaluation by a new panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard in administrative decision-making
Decision_Rationale: Board did not justify its departure from PRRA findings despite similar facts; lack of transparency and intelligibility

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making false statements to obtain benefit under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of refugee claim decision
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Found inconsistencies in testimony, lack of corroboration, and implausibilities
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimonial evidence, lack of corroborative documentation
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged persecution due to sexual orientation
Crimes.Application_Factor: Claimant's ability to demonstrate need for protection

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of refugee claim decision
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution based on sexual orientation in U.S. Army
Crimes.Legal_Framework: International refugee law, domestic immigration law
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Denial of refugee protection by IRB
Crimes.Government_Body_or_Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Adequate remedies available within U.S. military system
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Fear of punishment due to desertion and sexual orientation
Crimes.Credibility: Contradictions in testimony and lack of evidence
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Presumption of state protection not rebutted

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with military duty
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: U.S. Uniform Code of Military Justice
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant failed to meet military duties and sought refugee status in Canada
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Irrelevant – claim based on fear of return
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistent claims about treatment and options in U.S. military
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Canadian assessment of foreign military conduct
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of corroborating evidence for alleged persecution
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistent testimony and implausible narrative
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: US capable of providing adequate protection; alternative remedies available
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Application_Facts: Applicants were denied citizenship due to insufficient physical presence; applicants were abroad during assessment period
Residency_Compliance: Not met – insufficient physical presence in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Failure to review residency questionnaires; lack of fair hearing
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Judge did not consider submitted questionnaires
Decision_Outcome: Appeal allowed
Outcome: Remitted for reconsideration by a different citizenship judge
Remedy_Sought: Rehearing with procedural fairness
Legal_Standard_Applied: Section 5(1)(c) residency requirement; principles of procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: Applicants failed to meet residency requirement; judge erred in not providing fair opportunity to present case
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship judge, Federal Court Trial Division

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Residency obligation appeal with humanitarian and compassionate considerations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board committed an error of law or made a patently unreasonable finding of fact
Crimes.Outcome: Application allowed, case remanded for redetermination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant faced credibility issues due to inconsistent explanations, employment records, and financial evidence
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 28 - Residency obligations (730 days in 5 years)
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Patently unreasonable finding by ignoring relevant evidence
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review of Immigration Appeal Division decision
Crimes.Application_Error: Overly harsh assessment and dismissal of credible evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Permanent resident must be physically present in Canada for at least 730 days in any five-year period
Crimes.Application_Factor: Conflicting evidence on residency and lifestyle as a loan shark
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remanded for reconsideration by a different Board member

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with residency obligations
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 28 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant provided conflicting evidence about presence in Canada
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Permanent resident appealing loss of status
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistencies in travel records, employment, and finances
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of Immigration Appeal Division under IRPA
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Overlooked bank statements and veterinary visits
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Questioned due to inconsistencies in documentation
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Redetermination by a different Board member
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Board ignored relevant evidence and focused improperly on applicant's profession

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Residency determination with suspicion of financial misconduct
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of the Board’s factual findings on residency
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Conflicting travel, employment, and financial evidence
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate compliance with residency
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Must be physically present in Canada for 730 days in 5 years
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Unreasonable rejection of evidence and credibility findings
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Section 28
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Provided documentation to support residency claims

Crimes.Violation_Type: Improper consideration of irrelevant factors in residency assessment
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant engaged in loan sharking; Board used this to dismiss residency evidence
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Permanent resident appealing loss of status
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Disputed due to credibility and evidentiary issues
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Improper reliance on irrelevant conduct (loan sharking)
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Scope of Board’s authority under IRPA
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Relevant evidence dismissed due to applicant's profession
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negatively impacted by association with loan sharking, though unrelated to residency
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Patent unreasonableness standard applied to factual findings
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Board ignored credible evidence solely because of applicant's occupation

Violation_Type: Procedural error in assessment of subjective fear and credibility
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), sections related to refugee protection and determination
Governing_Law: Canadian refugee law, including principles on delay, credibility, and cumulative persecution
Application_Facts: Applicant is of Armenian ethnicity in Azerbaijan; claimed persecution due to ethnic background; reported cumulative incidents of discrimination and harassment
Procedural_Issue: Board failed to adequately analyze cumulative incidents; overemphasized delay in filing without proper justification
Evidence_Used: Testimony of applicant, history of discrimination and harassment based on ethnicity
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient analysis of credibility and subjective fear despite presence of credible evidence
Credibility_Assessment: Board questioned credibility due to delay and inconsistencies, but court found such concerns inadequately justified
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim initially denied by Immigration and Refugee Board
Remedy_Sought: Remand for redetermination
Legal_Standard_Applied: Subjective fear of persecution, credibility assessment, treatment of delay under refugee law
Decision_Rationale: Delay is relevant but not determinative; cumulative incidents may constitute persecution; failure to properly assess these factors rendered decision unreasonable
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section of the Citizenship Act requiring 1,095 days of physical presence
Application_Facts: Applicant Dedaj was short of required physical presence days but had established ties to Canada
Residency_Compliance: Incomplete physical presence; qualitative factors not assessed
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship judge failed to apply the qualitative test for residency
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of analysis regarding applicant's Canadian ties during relevant period
Decision_Outcome: Original application dismissed due to insufficient physical presence days
Remedy_Sought: Remand for reassessment by another citizenship judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: Both physical presence and qualitative residency tests under the Citizenship Act
Decision_Rationale: Legal error occurred by omitting the qualitative assessment of residency despite potential ties to Canada
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship Commission (via citizenship judge), Federal Court on review

Crimes.Legal_Provision: s. 72(1)(e)(i) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations

Crimes.Crime_Name: Criminality leading to inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Criminal inadmissibility due to family member's conviction
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant's son was under 22 at time of application, making him a dependent child
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Not met due to family member inadmissibility
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Whether s. 42 applies to permanent residency requirements
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Son's conviction accepted as valid
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Reapplication once son is no longer a dependent
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Dependent child's criminal inadmissibility affects principal applicant

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the Officer correctly apply humanitarian and compassionate grounds for exemption from permanent residence requirements?
Crimes.Outcome: Federal Court dismissed the judicial review application
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds based on integration and Canadian-born children
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: No unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship found upon return to Brazil
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Existence of unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Exemption denied; application dismissed on review

Crimes.Violation_Type: Unlawful presence in Canada after visa expiration
Application_Facts: Applicants overstayed visas
Established lives in Canada
Had Canadian-born children
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Temporary residents who became out of status
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to maintain legal residency status
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Application for permanent residence from within Canada refused
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Exemption from applying for permanent residence outside Canada
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Permanent residence under humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations under Section 25 of IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No unusual hardship established to justify exemption

Violation_Type: Failure to meet burden of proof for refugee status
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), s. 96-98
Governing_Law: 1951 Refugee Convention, Canadian Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant is an Ahmadi Muslim who faced harassment in home country; continued religious practice and studies; incidents deemed isolated by Refugee Division
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Refugee Division's decision
Evidence_Used: Incidents of harassment due to Ahmadi faith
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of systematic evidence showing persecution
Insufficient objective justification for fear
Credibility_Assessment: Subjective fear acknowledged, but not objectively justified
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim denied
Outcome: Application dismissed; applicant remains ineligible for refugee status
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of Refugee Division's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Subjective fear + objectively justified risk of persecution based on Convention grounds
Decision_Rationale: Incidents were isolated and did not amount to systematic or serious discrimination constituting persecution
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Division, Immigration and Refugee Board; Federal Court on judicial review

Application_Facts: Manickan claimed refugee status but was rejected due to disbelief in his testimony despite relevant documentary evidence linking him to risks faced by Tamil males in Sri Lanka.
Procedural_Issue: Board dismissed claim based on incredibility without considering documentary evidence, violating legal standards.
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence linking claimant to risks faced by Tamil males in Sri Lanka
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider relevant documentary evidence supporting the claim
Credibility_Assessment: Finding of incredibility made by the Board
Decision_Outcome: Original decision set aside; application for judicial review allowed
Outcome: Case remanded for reconsideration by a new panel
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of refugee claim with proper assessment of all evidence
Legal_Standard_Applied: Subjective and objective branches of the refugee test
Decision_Rationale: A finding of incredibility does not automatically disqualify a claim if other evidence supports both branches of the refugee test; omission of documentary evidence rendered the decision unreasonable.

Crimes.Crime_Name: Serious criminality under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Brown served 17 months pre-trial; Crown suggested 2:1 credit; sentencing judge imposed 1 additional day in jail
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Permanent Resident or Protected Person (implied by deportation context)
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Whether pre-sentence incarceration counts toward the 'term of imprisonment'
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: IAD's jurisdiction to hear appeal based on length of sentence
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of clear judicial intent to grant 2:1 credit for pre-trial custody
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD erred in assuming automatic 2:1 credit
Crimes.Outcome: Deportation order based on serious criminality
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Pre-trial custody may count if considered part of punishment, but no automatic doubling without judicial intent

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Robbery with potential use of weapon (contextual link)
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Use of imitation firearm (linked to co-charge)
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Credit for pre-trial custody considered but not clearly applied
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High (indictable offence with potential for lengthy sentence)
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk due to violent nature and firearm involvement
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Potential for reoffending or threat to community
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient for conviction but ambiguity in sentencing details
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Credible but incomplete regarding credit application
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Inclusion and calculation of pre-trial custody toward two-year threshold under IRPA

Crimes.Crime_Name: Using an imitation firearm during the commission of an offence
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Use of imitation firearm increasing danger and severity
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: No explicit mention of harm caused or intent to fire
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk due to weapon involvement
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Ambiguity in whether pre-trial custody counted toward two-year threshold under IRPA
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Criminal Code – Using an imitation firearm (s. 88 or s. 344(a)(ii))

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to inform authorities of address change under Immigration Act
Legal_Issue: Does the statutory stay under s. 49(1)(c)(i) of the Immigration Act apply when an application for leave and judicial review is made out of time?
Outcome: Removal order stayed by operation of law under s. 49(1)(c)(i); no further court order required
Basis_of_Claim: Applicant missed deadline for judicial review due to failure to update address; sought extension and statutory stay
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Statutory stay applies even if application is late, per Mackay decision
Application_Error: Missed filing deadline for judicial review
Legal_Standard: Operation of statutory stay under s. 49(1)(c)(i)
Application_Factor: Intent to file judicial review despite late filing
Decision_Outcome: Stay effective by operation of law
Authority: Immigration Act, s. 49(1)(c)(i); Mackay's decision as precedent

Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act provisions on authorized stay
Application_Facts: Ziyadah overstayed visa, applied for refugee status, was rejected, filed judicial review late
Procedural_Issue: Late filing of judicial review application
Decision_Outcome: Removal order stayed by operation of law; motion for stay dismissed as unnecessary
Outcome: Statutory stay granted under s. 49(1)(c)(i) despite late filing
Relief_Sought: Stay of removal pending judicial review
Remedy_Sought: Extension of time to file judicial review
Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of s. 49(1)(c)(i) and applicability to late applications
Decision_Rationale: Consistency and rationality in law; adoption of Mackay’s reasoning

Application_Facts: Applicant was physically present for 507 days, falling short of the required 1,095 days within four years
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet the 1,095-day physical presence requirement
Procedural_Issue: Federal Court review under reasonableness standard
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence to meet exceptions or qualitative criteria for residency
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship application denied
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of the Citizenship Judge's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Physical presence test under section 5(1)(c)
Decision_Rationale: The Applicant did not accumulate the required 1,095 days of residence and failed to demonstrate eligibility under any exception or qualitative assessment
